title: ls_objects
contents:
Exploring R base function related to enviroment.
This is meant as examples of use, NOT as a tutorial or explanation of R’s environmental structure. Others do this much better:
-
ls() returns objects in character vector.


ls()  <- NULL


      ## Error in ls() <- NULL: invalid (NULL) left side of assignment

x  <- 2
y  <- 2*x
ls()


      ##  [1] "bundle"                  "f"                      
      ##  [3] "file"                    "get_batch"              
      ##  [5] "get_query_params"        "get_query_params.videos"
      ##  [7] "global_params"           "jim_lib"                
      ##  [9] "query_params"            "videos"                 
      ## [11] "x"                       "y"

ls() includes name of functions.


ls()


      ##  [1] "bundle"                  "f"                      
      ##  [3] "file"                    "get_batch"              
      ##  [5] "get_query_params"        "get_query_params.videos"
      ##  [7] "global_params"           "jim_lib"                
      ##  [9] "query_params"            "videos"                 
      ## [11] "x"                       "y"

f  <- function() {
  z  <- 2
}

ls()  # includes f


      ##  [1] "bundle"                  "f"                      
      ##  [3] "file"                    "get_batch"              
      ##  [5] "get_query_params"        "get_query_params.videos"
      ##  [7] "global_params"           "jim_lib"                
      ##  [9] "query_params"            "videos"                 
      ## [11] "x"                       "y"

environment is …. environment() returns , one of R’s typeof


environment()


      ## <environment: R_GlobalEnv>

typeof(environment())


      ## [1] "environment"

in fact, R has a whole tree of environments search


search()


      ##  [1] ".GlobalEnv"        "package:rmarkdown" "package:distill"  
      ##  [4] "devtools_shims"    "package:youtube "  "package:testthat" 
      ##  [7] "package:nvimcom"   "package:stats"     "package:graphics" 
      ## [10] "package:grDevices" "package:utils"     "package:datasets" 
      ## [13] "package:xfun"      "package:sloop"     "package:here"     
      ## [16] "package:lobstr"    "package:rlang"     "package:devtools" 
      ## [19] "package:usethis"   "package:reprex"    "package:methods"  
      ## [22] "Autoloads"         "package:base"

objects inside a packagea



# 1st 9
ls(envir=as.environment("package:usethis"))[1:9]


      ## [1] "browse_circleci"       "browse_cran"          
      ## [3] "browse_github"         "browse_github_actions"
      ## [5] "browse_github_issues"  "browse_github_pat"    
      ## [7] "browse_github_pulls"   "browse_github_token"  
      ## [9] "browse_package"

ls(envir=as.environment(“package:usethis”)) And you can add your own, sometimes R creates its won.
Example, Modify f


ls()


      ##  [1] "bundle"                  "f"                      
      ##  [3] "file"                    "get_batch"              
      ##  [5] "get_query_params"        "get_query_params.videos"
      ##  [7] "global_params"           "jim_lib"                
      ##  [9] "query_params"            "videos"                 
      ## [11] "x"                       "y"


f  <- function() {
  z  <- 2
  print(environment())
  print(ls())
}

ls()  # includes f and g


      ##  [1] "bundle"                  "f"                      
      ##  [3] "file"                    "get_batch"              
      ##  [5] "get_query_params"        "get_query_params.videos"
      ##  [7] "global_params"           "jim_lib"                
      ##  [9] "query_params"            "videos"                 
      ## [11] "x"                       "y"



f()


      ## <environment: 0x55cdd1dc1088>
      ## [1] "z"

title: post_upgrade_notes
description: A short description of the post.
contents:
R Update Notes

Each time I update R, I seem to run into trouble with one or more directories that R uses. The reasons probably relate to switching from RStudio to another IDE (neovim) or compiling from source one time and using binaries the next.
To sort it out, I found this the Ubuntu/Debian instructions helpful: https://ftp.osuosl.org/pub/cran/bin/linux/debian
But first, I had to remove all the old R installations. Then I followed directions for Debian binary installation. In particular, the section https://ftp.osuosl.org/pub/cran/bin/linux/debian explains where the environment variables are set.
So here I collect useful R environment variables I found to be important. To ease navigation, I also set shell environment variables (I use zsh ) to match R. Of course, your experience will differ, but getting a good grasp on the R environment variables may avoid some future pain.


R_env  <- c("R_HOME", 
            "R_LIBS_USER", 
            "R_LIBS_SITE",
            NA,
            NA) 

paths  <- c("/usr/lib/R/",
            "/home/jim/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.1/",
            "/usr/lib/R/library/",
            "/etc/R/Renviron",
            "~/.Renviron")

zsh_env  <- c("R_HOME", 
            "R_LIBS_USER", 
            "R_LIBS_SITE",
            NA,
            NA)



dt  <- data.table(R_env = R_env,
                  path = paths,
                  zsh_env = zsh_env)


dt %>% knitr::kable()


R_env
path
zsh_env
R_HOME
/usr/lib/R/
R_HOME
R_LIBS_USER
/home/jim/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.1/
R_LIBS_USER
R_LIBS_SITE
/usr/lib/R/library/
R_LIBS_SITE
NA
/etc/R/Renviron
NA
NA
~/.Renviron
NA

Special notes
Ending slash indicates a directory: /usr/lib/R/library/
A file has no ending slash: ~/.Renviron
The file Renviron in directory /etc/R/ sets many environment variables, including $R_LIBS_SITE, which designates one more directories for packages.
I modified this to include only one directory: /usr/lib/R/library/
Because there are a couple of ways to install R packages (from Debian, from source, from inside R, …) I may decide to modify this later to expand possibily directories for R packages.
(future) There are other environment variables that may be useful, for example R_ENVIRON, R_ENVIRON_USER but I did not use these.
Here is one way to confirm which directories R is using for packages.


.libPaths()


      ## [1] "/home/jim/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.1"
      ## [2] "/usr/lib/R/library"

Another way is through Sys.getenv() to find R env variables
R_HOME
R_LIBS_SITE
R_LIBS_USER


s  <- Sys.getenv()
names  <- names(s)
head(names)


      ## [1] "_R_CHECK_COMPILATION_FLAGS_KNOWN_"
      ## [2] "API_KEY"                          
      ## [3] "CLICOLOR_FORCE"                   
      ## [4] "DBUS_SESSION_BUS_ADDRESS"         
      ## [5] "DEFAULTS_PATH"                    
      ## [6] "DESKTOP_SESSION"

head(s[grep(pattern = "^R", x = names)])


      ## R_ARCH               
      ## R_BROWSER            xdg-open
      ## R_BZIPCMD            /bin/bzip2
      ## R_DOC_DIR            /usr/share/R/doc
      ## R_GZIPCMD            /bin/gzip -n
      ## R_HIST_SIZE          1000

s[grep(pattern = "^R_LIBS", x = names)]


      ## R_LIBS               
      ## R_LIBS_SITE          library:/usr/lib/R/library
      ## R_LIBS_USER          ~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.1



if (F) help(.libPaths)



Troubleshooting
R –vanilla
Running RStudio requires R be compiled with ….
Orignal motivation for this particular upgrade was to install RStudio (I normally use neovim + nvim-R plug in) and have not installed RStudio.
Unfortunately, I did not do this; RStudio’s error msg not too friendly.
I decided to use R binaries, and so followed this webpage https://ftp.osuosl.org/pub/cran/ and this …. R –vanilla worked, but not R. Problems with where installed R puts things, local, lib etc.


knitr::knit_exit()

title: R odds and ends
contents:
Misc R
base R only, collect here
unlist
dput
save
Not so keen on else if construct.


# ======================
## if - else if - else
# ======================

f  <- function(x) {
  if (x <0) {cat("less than 0")}
  else if(x<1) {cat("less than 1")}
  else if(x<2) {cat("less than 2")}
  else if(x<3) {cat("less than 3")}
  else if(x<4) {cat("less than 4")}
  else {cat("4 or greater")}
}

x <- -1
f(x)


      ## less than 0

f(x <- x+1)


      ## less than 1

f(x  <- x+1)


      ## less than 2

f(x  <- x+1)


      ## less than 3

x


      ## [1] 2

But ifelse(boolean, true , false) is very handy.


#  
# ======================
##    ifelse
# ======================
ifelse(5>3, "yes", "no")


      ## [1] "yes"

x  <- c(1,5,10)
# return vector of length(x) and each element 'yes' or 'no'
ifelse(x > 5, "yes", "no")  # 'no' 'no' 'yes'


      ## [1] "no"  "no"  "yes"

switch


x<-2
x  <- "B"
x  <- 3
base::switch(x, "first", 
             B = "second",
             C = "third"
)


      ## [1] "third"

choose  <- function(x) {

    base::switch(x, "first", 
             B = "second",
             C = "third",
             x
)

}

x  <- 3
x <- 100
choose(x)



in named vector, names are attributes


# ----------------------
## create named vector
# ----------------------
    x  <- 1:5
    # [1] 1 2 3 4 5

    names(x)  <- letters[1:5]
    x


      ## a b c d e 
      ## 1 2 3 4 5

    # a b c d e 
    # 1 2 3 4 5 

    attributes(x)


      ## $names
      ## [1] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e"

# ----------------------------------------
## now, remove the names: couple of ways
# ----------------------------------------

  x.1  <- unname(x)
# [1] 1 2 3 4 5


## another way to remove names
  x.2  <- x
  names(x.2)  <- NULL
  x.2


      ## [1] 1 2 3 4 5

# [1] 1 2 3 4 5

## also
  x.3  <- as.numeric(x)
# [1] 1 2 3 4 5



expand relative file name


file <- "BASE/0296_base_R_misc.Rmd"
normalizePath(file)


      ## [1] "BASE/0296_base_R_misc.Rmd"

path.expand(file)


      ## [1] "BASE/0296_base_R_misc.Rmd"

path.expand("~")


      ## [1] "/home/jim"


```{.r .distill-force-highlighting-css}

title: post_THREE
description: A short description of the post.
contents:
post_THREE
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing, native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

title: Useful reading
contents:
As of 
R - always learn something new:
Peng, https://bookdown.org/rdpeng/rprogdatascience/
Hadley, https://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html
Gillespie (2016) https://bookdown.org/csgillespie/efficientR/
Matloff: Appendix A
R - more advanced
official CRAN: https://cran.r-project.org/manuals.html
design.tidyverse.org
Basic Statistics
PSU Course begin with 414 | | no R
https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat414/
https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat462/
https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat415/

AMS Basic, good intro CLT (but not t)
Dekking, et al Modern Introduction to Probability & Statistics (2005), no R.
Faraday, PRAR: Practical Regression, Anova, linear algebra (mature approach)
Frey, Bruce “Statistical Hacks”
Matloff (Prob book)
http://heather.cs.ucdavis.edu/~matloff/132/PLN/probstatbook/ProbStatBook.pdf
(via pdflatex) https://github.com/matloff/probstatbook Good, maybe too good and skips a few basics?

Siegrist CLT, stats, linear alg | aka randomservices.org | ** best book for introducing Math
More advanced regession/modeling books
Shalizi: excellent:
http://www.stat.cmu.edu/~cshalizi/TALR/
Shalizi http://www.stat.cmu.edu/~cshalizi/ADAfaEPoV/ADAfaEPoV.pdf
http://www.stat.cmu.edu/~cshalizi/mreg/15/

Linear Algebra
Level 1 (start)
Beezer Linear Algebra
0 stats, but good review for me, right level

Bendixcarstensen.com, with R & matrix models (try not use api pkg)
http://www.bendixcarstensen.com/APC/linalg-notes-BxC.pdf

Level 2
Herve Adbi | lin alg| no R, no stat, starts simple but gets to decomposition.
Thomas, Math for ML … good lin alg, but quickly gets advanced. https://gwthomas.github.io/docs/math4ml.pdf
Deisenroth, Faiesel et al | Math4ML *book | linear alg book, regression, 2nd level
Strang, Linear Algebra (classic)
Taubes, linear alg, statistics, http://people.math.harvard.edu/~knill/teaching/math19b_2011/handouts/chapters1-19.pdf
Also
Artin, Michael “Algebra” - readable ?
Davidson (Econometric) - Ch 1, 2
Friendly - R Pkg linear algebra
Kazan | normal equations
Rafael genomics - Chapter 4 matrix
More intuitive, less coding (R) math
Przemyslaw Biecek and Tomasz Burzykowski | different ideas | Explanatory Model Analysis
https://ema.drwhy.ai/

REGRESSION, ML, MODELING BOOKS
Boehmke Hands on ML | https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/
Compeau:
great ideas book! http://compeau.cbd.cmu.edu/ |
http://compeau.cbd.cmu.edu/programming-for-lovers/ cmu - ch 8, 9 esp collinear.

Efron, Hastie “Computer Age Statistical Inference” (advanced, but chapter intros put techniques into perspective), no R.
hannay (=rbassett) read, but avoid code + its pkgs ch 11, 12 |
https://faculty.nps.edu/rbassett/_book/

Harrell, glossary: http://hbiostat.org/doc/glossary.pdf
ismay modern dive (2020)
Jennybc (book) * ch18-20
kaplan (2017) ch 6.5
kuhn (2019) fes * no r, not an intro. book.
kurz
lane se(b_hat)
MATLOFF (1st book) * ch3 - lot of useful prproperties of x,y * ch 7 - affine transformations
matloff(2020) book
mcelreath (videos)
navarro (learn statistics with r) review lm() and geometric r^2
navarro 2019 (learn statistics with r) study output of lm()
PENG
art of ... (2017) ch 6.5
r4ds             (2019) ch 9.5

RAFAEL dsbook - ch 17.4, ch 18.3.4
Roback/Legler Beyond Multiple Linear Regression: (2021)_ https://bookdown.org/roback/bookdown-BeyondMLR/ (Replaces BYSH)
Siegrist (aka random services.org)
random| (3)expected value 1..11 and |(5) random samples 1-8 (t-dist)

mosaic ch 5.6, ch 24
Good Technical Reading
Math 4 Machine Learning https://mml-book.github.io/book/mml-book.pdf
Latex: Latex in 24 hours (iPad)
Linux: Archiwiki, Debian, FreeBSD
Gross, Ash et al “Elliptical Tales” - very readable, but must think! (515.983 | ASH | 2012)
Videos
[maththebeautiful - Paul?]https://www.youtube.com/c/MathTheBeautiful/playlists
Bright Side of Math
3Blue1Brown
Zedstatistics

title: Welcome to blog5
description:
Welcome to our new blog, blog5. We hope you enjoy 
reading what we have to say!
